name: Anna Xambó
bio: I am a researcher and musician. My research and practice focus on building and evaluating interactive music systems for music creation and performance using human-computer interaction research. I am a Senior Lecturer in Sound and Music Computing and a member of the Centre for Digital Music (C4DM) at Queen Mary University of London.

name: Matt Wilkinson
bio: I am a Senior Climate Scientist at Forest Research. The focus of my research is to improve our understanding of forest carbon and greenhouse gas (GHG) balances and how they may be impacted by management, environmental and climate change. I am also interested in developing new techniques and sensors for trace gas flux measurements and forest monitoring.

name: Luigi Marino
bio: I am a Research Fellow in Sound and Music Computing at Queen Mary University of London. The focus of my work is on networks able to display relationships between human and nonhuman actors. I am an active improvisor performing on both electronic media and percussion.

name: Peter Batchelor
bio: I am a Senior Lecturer and Programme Leader in Music Technology, and member of the Music, Technology and Innovation - Institute of Sonic Creativity (MTI2) at De Montfort University, Leicester. My creative activities encompass a range of electroacoustic composition and sound-making work, including radiophonic documentary, live-electronics and improvisation, multimedia and large-scale multi-channel installation work.

name: Hazel Stone
bio: I am the National Curator of Contemporary Art at Forestry England. I have an established career that spans curating and commissioning contemporary art in the landscape, exhibition design, artist development, and learning. My portfolio includes roles such as Curator of the Sidney Cooper Gallery, Director of Curious Planet, Lecturer and Arts Development Manager for the North of England for Forestry England, as well as Curator for Grizedale Forest.

name: Aleksander Skutnik
bio: I am a BSc Computer Science final year student at Queen Mary University of London. For my final year project, I have decided to undertake a research based topic within the Sensing the Forest project under the supervision of Dr Anna Xambó and Kok Ho Huen. My areas of interest and academic experience include probabilistic algorithms and risk analysis, as well as research experience in cognitive and sociocultural areas of psychology.

name: Mahmoud B. Elmokadem
bio: Mahmoud Elmokadem (Emerging Technologies Research Centre, De Montfort University, Leicester, United Kingdom) is a highly motivated mechanical engineer and researcher with extensive expertise in control systems, mechatronics, and advanced materials. His career spans academia, industry, and start-ups, combining deep technical knowledge with strategic project management experience. He is adept at aligning engineering innovation with commercial objectives, making him ideally positioned to lead product development, manage new and ongoing projects, and drive collaborative success across technical and business teams. Currently undertaking a PhD in Mechanical Acoustic Metamaterials, Elmokadem brings a strong research foundation and a commitment to delivering sustainable, high-performance solutions. He is passionate about innovation in fast-paced environments and plays a key role in supporting the company's technical roadmap and commercial growth.

name: Krishna Nama Manjunatha
bio: Krishna Nama Manjunatha (Emerging Technologies Research Centre, De Montfort University, Leicester, United Kingdom) is a Senior Lecturer in microelectronics and nanoelectronics at De Montfort University and works within the Emerging Technologies Research Centre. His PhD in Nanomaterials for Photovoltaic Applications won the ‘‘Best PhD Thesis of the Year’’. He leads research based on emerging materials for energy related applications, specialising in self-doped silicon nanowires (SiNWs) for energy-related applications. His research is further focused in the field of wide-bandgap semiconductors, synthesis of materials for solar cells, Li- & Na-ion batteries and thermoelectric applications. His entrepreneurial mindset is demonstrated through successful ideation, prototyping, and commercial grant acquisition for lab-to-market transitions of innovative micro/nano-scale manufacturing tools.

name: Sofia Zahri
bio: Sofia Zahri is a highly motivated, keen and hard working computer network and AI PhD researcher based in London. Sofia is working on the innovative area of biomedical engineering focusing on infectious disease outbreaks forecasting and Federated learning techniques.

name: Daniel Gill
bio: Daniel Gill is a PhD student in Computer Science at Queen Mary University of London under the supervision of Dr Ekaterina Ivanova and Prof Rachael Bedford. He previously received a bachelor's degree in computer science and master's degree in computer science by research from Queen Mary University of London. His research explores the intersection of psychological theories for autistic perception, robotic-aided haptic interaction and communication, and design practices for neurodivergent technology users.

name: Stanley Parker
bio: Stanley Parker is a BSc Creative Computing student at Queen Mary University of London. He is creating an environmental monitoring module for his final year project and is working with the Sensing the Forest team to help make this happen and is being supervised for his project by Dr Anna Xambó and Kok Ho Huen. His areas of experience include sound design and generative audio, interactive media design, web programming, working with sensors and data mapping. Stanley also has an interest in music and audio production, conservation and general use of computers and other digital media in association with the natural world.

name: Nico García
bio: Nico García is a Computer Music Researcher based in London.

name: Xinyue Xu
bio: Xinyue Xu is a MSc Sound and Music Computing student in EECS at Queen Mary University of London. She participates in the Sensing the Forest project, focusing on research in parameter mapping sonification and interactive music systems and under the supervision of Dr. Anna Xambó. Her research interests center on translating meteorological sensor data into sound and enhancing the understanding of the connection between forests and climate change through sonification techniques. She is also interested in immersive audio, 3D binaural sound rendering, and spatial hearing.

name: Tug F. O’Flaherty
bio: Tug O’Flaherty is a Sound and Music Computing MSc student at Queen Mary University of London. Having previously undertaken a BSc (Hons) in Computer Science at Kingston University, he specialises in web and cross-platform mobile application development. Tug is excited to be applying his software development background to producing an interactive tool for the sonification and visualisation of climate and tree data within the Sensing the Forest project, under the direction of Dr Anna Xambó. He is passionate about climate change awareness and community-focussed initiatives, and keen to contribute his expertise in data mappings, music, and web development.

name: Shane Robinson
bio: I built this...and a lot of other things over the past 23+ years as a founder, developer, sys admin, and database architect. I taught myself to code in B.A.S.I.C. in 1983/4 on a Commodore 64 hooked up to my 13 in. black/white TV. Then we built large CMS systems in the 90s using PERL, SSI, and eventually the early versions of PHP. This was all years before Wordpress even existed. Fast forward to 2017 when I semi-retired from coding to spend more time on my Art practice. In early 2020 I wanted to throw a small ecommerce website together and planned to build it in HUGO (like I previously had with my own personal website.) After some research I found 11ty and knew I finally had a set of tools to quickly build secure, fast, fun-to-code websites. Not finding exactly what I wanted in a starter project/template, I built this to use as a template for turning out small sites and migrating several of our Wordpress sites to static.

name: Roxanne Darling
bio: Roxanne Darling loves to travel, speak in public, be on and in the ocean, and is giving up working really long hours. She walks the line between technology and communication with a ballerina’s balance (she used to dance at the Palo Alto Dance Theatre and is a certified yoga instructor) and has a way of inspiring even luddites to try new things with technology. Please let it be known though, perhaps as a graduate of UC Berkeley, she is not a bystander or interested in the status quo!

personalWebsites.label: I Am: For The Love Of Nature

name: Shuoyang Zheng
bio: Shuoyang Zheng is a PhD student at the Centre for Digital Music (C4DM), Queen Mary University of London. His research is in the field of explainable AI for musical audio synthesis. His long-term research goal focuses on developing interactive and understandable AI systems that facilitate musical creation and expression, and on understanding how these technological advances impact artistic practices. He is equally interested in the aesthetical and ethical implications inherent to the development of AI.
